Pre-pharmacy, pre-med, liberal arts, locals, minorities.

Check out the campus and surrounding area. Definitely sit in on classes that interest you, and most importantly: try to talk to current students to get a feel for the campus atmosphere. The people in admissions and financial aid offices were really rude to me when I was applying. I actually decided not to go to Xavier for many reasons, but also because I could not believe how I was being treated by the staff just for simply asking if my file was complete for application ad if they'd received all my test scores, etc. I didn't want to deal with this for the next four years. I go to Loyola University New Orleans now and love it.
Xavier is relatively cheap for what it offers, but since it is not extremely well known it does not get as much private endowment to use towards financial aid.

I think that Xavier is really not in the best part of New Orleans, and I wouldn't like living there. There is a big commuter population at Xavier and the ages of incoming students ranges greatly. All told it is not for me because these factors make the school less of a community.
The professors at Xavier seemed very good. They were interested in helping students learn, and there seemed to be a good student-faculty relationship.
